Comparing execution time with varying processors

Diana Betelli

2025-04-09

Source: vignettes/Execution_time_cores.Rmd
Execution_time_cores.Rmd

Introduction

PscanR analyzes large datasets, such as promoter regions and Transcription Factor Binding Motifs. To improve performance and reduce computation time, the tool supports parallel computing.

Two main functions utilize the BiocParallel package for parallelization: ps_build_bg() and pscan(). While the first is used for background generation, the second is the core function of PscanR. This vignette focuses on analyzing how varying the number of cores passed to the bpparam() function (one of pscan()’s inputs) affects execution time.

The default BPPARAM value in pscan() is bpparam(), which automatically selects the parallelization type and number of cores based on the system.

Experimental conditions

The experiment uses the largest list of co-regulated or co-expressed genes available on the Pscan platform. These genes are sampled from human liver tissue. Promoter regions are defined as those extending 950 bp upstream and 50 bp downstream from the Transcription Start Site (TSS). The number of cores tested includes: 1, 2, 4, 6, 8, 12, 18, and 24.

Note that the observed speedup will depend on the dimension of the data.

Parallelization models

The two main computational models used for parallelization are:

  • SnowParam (Distributed Memory Computing): The SNOW model used by SnowParam() is suitable for all operating systems, especially Windows, which does not support process forking.

  • MulticoreParam (Shared Memory Computing): Uses forking, which is generally more efficient than SNOW but is only supported on Unix-based systems (Linux/macOS).

Both models are analyzed in this vignette.

Retrieving promoter sequences 

# Import gtf annotation from UCSC
txdb <- txdbmaker::makeTxDbFromUCSC(genome="hg38", 
                                    tablename="ncbiRefSeqCurated")

# Select only canonical chromosomes 
GenomeInfoDb::seqlevels(txdb) <- GenomeInfoDb::seqlevels(txdb)[1:24] 

# Background generation. JASPAR core dataset for Vertebrates, 2020 release
J2020_PSBG <- PscanR::generate_psmatrixlist_from_background( 'Jaspar2020', 
                                                             'hs', 
                                                             c(-950,50), 
                                                             'hg38') 

# Retrieve promoter regions 
prom_rng <- GenomicFeatures::promoters(txdb, 
                                       upstream = 950, 
                                       downstream = 50, 
                                       use.names = TRUE) 

# Version numbers removal from transcript IDs
prom_rng$tx_name_clean <- sub("\\..*$", "", prom_rng$tx_name) 

# Retrieve target sequence identifiers. You can download it from the official 
# Pscan platform
target <- read.csv("processori/liver.txt", header = F) 

# Filters promoter regions corresponding to the target gene list
prom_range <- prom_rng[prom_rng$tx_name_clean %in% target[,1]] 

# Extract sequences
prom_seq <- Biostrings::getSeq(x = BSgenome.Hsapiens.UCSC.hg38, prom_range)

MulticoreParam

Execution Time Script

The following script will return a data frame with 8 columns, corresponding to the different number of cores. Rows represent the number of iteration. Each row contains the evaluated time for each core.

iterations <- 100 # Number of iterations
core_numbers <- c(1,2,4,6,8,12,18,24) # Cores used

execution_time <- function(prom_seq, bg, ncores, output_file){
  temp <- numeric(iterations)
  
  for (i in 1:iterations){
    timing <- system.time({
      results <- PscanR::pscan(prom_seq, 
                               bg, 
                               BPPARAM = BiocParallel::MulticoreParam(ncores))}
      ) 
    if (i == 1){
      saveRDS(PscanR::ps_results_table(results), output_file) 
# Analyse all the files to be sure that results don't change when changing 
# the core numbers
      }
    temp[i] <- timing["elapsed"]
    }
  return(temp)
  }

all_cores <- function(core_numbers, prom_seq, bg, iterations) {
  results_list <- list()
  
  for (core in core_numbers) {
    output_file <- paste0("core", core, "_liver_950d_50u.rds")
    results_list[[as.character(core)]] <- execution_time(prom_seq, 
                                                         bg, 
                                                         core, 
                                                         output_file)
  }
  
  return(as.data.frame(results_list))
} 

df_processori <- all_cores(core_numbers, prom_seq, bg_hg38_2020, iterations)
colnames(df_processori) <- core_numbers

saveRDS(df_processori, "df_processori.rds")

Analysis of the timing

The following chuck of code produce a plot useful to analyse the evaluated times.

file_path <- system.file("extdata", "df_processori.rds", package = "PscanR")
data<- readRDS(file_path)

head(data)
#>          1       2       4       6       8      12      18      24
#> 1 1767.890 852.253 596.281 305.782 219.894 161.797 153.600 145.734
#> 2 1740.151 846.159 532.302 303.908 224.798 156.721 156.424 144.342
#> 3 1749.970 843.135 544.599 304.279 224.203 155.231 154.705 140.246
#> 4 1796.453 842.264 536.799 307.421 222.347 156.589 149.378 143.254
#> 5 1826.954 851.207 538.372 302.336 219.488 157.301 150.235 142.237
#> 6 1804.675 847.565 543.066 302.385 221.547 163.174 152.226 141.508

N <- as.numeric(colnames(data))
means <- colMeans(data, na.rm = TRUE)

# Power regression
power_model <- lm(log(means) ~ log(N))  

smooth_N <- seq(min(N), max(N), length.out = 500)  # 500 punti tra 1 e 24
smooth_pred <- exp(predict(power_model, newdata = data.frame(N = smooth_N)))  

ss_total <- sum((means - mean(means))^2)
ss_residual <- sum((means - exp(predict(power_model)))^2)
r_squared <- 1 - (ss_residual / ss_total) 
boxplot(data,
        main = "PscanR Execution Time with MulticoreParam",
        xlab = "Cores (N)\nLiver dataset (950d−50u), JASPAR2020 (746 matrices), 329 promoters (1000bp)",
        cex.lab = 0.8,
        ylab = "Time (s)",
        col = "lightblue",
        las = 1, names = N, outline = FALSE)

lines(smooth_N, smooth_pred, col = "blue", lwd = 2)

legend("topright", legend = bquote("Power regression, " ~ R^2 == .(round(r_squared, 3))),
       col = "blue", lwd = 2)

Consideration

As shown in the boxplot, the execution time decreases significantly as the number of processors increases, but beyond 8 cores, the performance gains plateaus. This suggests that using more than 8 cores offers little additional benefits.

SnowParam

Execution Time Script

See MulticoreParam section for the detailed script. The only thing that changes is the BPPARAM parameter. We use BPPARAM = BiocParallel::SnowParam(ncores)). As before, we obtain a data frame with 8 columns, corresponding to the different number of cores. Rows represent the number of iteration. Each row contains the evaluated time for each core.

Analysis of the timing 

file_path <- system.file("extdata", "df_processori_SnowParam.rds", 
                         package = "PscanR")
data <- readRDS(file_path)

head(data)
#>          1       2       4       6       8      12      18      24
#> 1 1594.546 840.533 457.702 339.265 300.127 272.745 286.095 350.646
#> 2 1584.279 826.880 460.332 338.085 296.227 276.088 314.513 353.036
#> 3 1628.185 824.053 460.498 338.169 298.156 270.094 306.451 362.647
#> 4 1654.207 828.324 457.738 340.431 281.212 281.753 301.324 365.110
#> 5 1654.022 827.805 464.290 334.106 294.103 266.921 276.345 370.115
#> 6 1651.168 838.438 462.661 332.737 299.474 281.973 298.957 369.012

N <- as.numeric(colnames(data))
means <- colMeans(data, na.rm = TRUE)

# Power regression
power_model <- lm(log(means) ~ log(N))  

smooth_N <- seq(min(N), max(N), length.out = 500)  # 500 punti tra 1 e 24
smooth_pred <- exp(predict(power_model, newdata = data.frame(N = smooth_N)))  

ss_total <- sum((means - mean(means))^2)
ss_residual <- sum((means - exp(predict(power_model)))^2)
r_squared <- 1 - (ss_residual / ss_total)
boxplot(data,
        main = "PscanR Execution Time with SnowParam",
        xlab = "Cores (N)\nLiver dataset (950d−50u), JASPAR2020 (746 matrices), 
        329 promoters (1000bp)",
        cex.lab = 0.8,
        ylab = "Time (s)",
        col = "lightblue",
        las = 1, names = N, outline = FALSE)

lines(smooth_N, smooth_pred, col = "blue", lwd = 2)

legend("topright", legend = bquote("Power regression, " ~ R^2 == .(round(r_squared, 3))),
       col = "blue", lwd = 2)

Final Remarks

This vignette demonstrated the impact of parallelization on PscanR execution time. The results show that MulticoreParam is more efficient but limited to Unix systems, while SnowParam ensures compatibility across all platforms. A plateau in performance gain beyond 12 cores suggests an optimal configuration for parallel execution.
